name: Being and Time: Introduction - The Question of the Meaning of Being

keyTerms.definition: The entity which each of us is, characterized by its questioning relationship to Being
Not itself a being, but that which makes beings intelligible as beings
The inquiry into the meaning of Being through analysis of Dasein's Being
Distinction between particular beings and the Being that makes beings intelligible
The mode of Being of objects considered as mere things present before a theoretical observer
The mode of Being of equipment encountered in practical engagement with the world

secondarySources: Richardson - Heidegger: Through Phenomenology to Thought (1963)

children.name: Diagnosing the Forgetfulness of Being
children.subtitle: Why the question of Being has been neglected and trivialized

items.name: The question of Being has been forgotten despite metaphysical revival
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. Heidegger claims that contemporary philosophy, despite considering itself progressive in affirming metaphysics, has forgotten the fundamental question of Being that animated Plato and Aristotle.

items.name: Ancient achievements have become trivialized through transmission
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. The fragmentary insights of ancient thinkers, preserved through alterations down to Hegel's logic, have lost their original provocative character and become commonplace.

items.name: A dogma has developed declaring Being the most universal and empty concept
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. Traditional ontology treats 'Being' as indefinable due to its universality, making further questioning appear methodologically erroneous.

items.name: Ancient ontology interpreted Being through presence-at-hand
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. The roots of neglect lie in ancient ontology's interpretation of beings in terms of 'world' or 'Nature' and understanding Being through the temporal mode of presence.

items.name: The Western metaphysical tradition operates within an unexamined understanding of temporality
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: IMPLICIT. Heidegger assumes that traditional ontology's privileging of presence reveals an uncritical acceptance of linear time that must be exposed and overcome.

children.name: The Ontological Difference and Being's Indefinability
children.subtitle: Establishing Being's unique logical status

items.name: Being is not itself a being
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. The fundamental ontological difference (ontologische Differenz): Being (Sein) cannot be treated as an entity (Seiendes) among entities but is rather the condition that makes beings intelligible as beings.

items.name: Being cannot be defined through genus and differentia
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. Being resists traditional definition through higher or lower concepts because it is the condition for all conceptual determination.

items.name: Indefinability does not mean Being is meaningless
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. Against the dogma of Being's emptiness, Heidegger argues that Being's indefinability through beings does not render it conceptually vacuous.

items.name: Being cannot be conceived as a being but requires its own mode of approach
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. The ontological difference demands a new methodology that does not apply categories appropriate to beings when investigating Being.

items.name: Ontic vs Ontological distinction
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. Ontic concerns particular facts about beings; ontological concerns the Being of beings. Traditional metaphysics conflates these levels of analysis.

items.name: Language adequately expresses Being despite its non-conceptual character
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: IMPLICIT. Heidegger assumes that philosophical language, properly deployed, can meaningfully articulate Being's meaning without reducing Being to a being.

children.name: The Formal Structure of Fundamental Ontology
children.subtitle: The circular but productive structure of questioning Being through Dasein

items.name: All questioning has a triadic structure: what is asked about, what is asked, and what is questioned
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. Questioning involves: (1) das Gefragte (what is asked about - Being), (2) das Erfragte (what is asked - meaning of Being), (3) das Befragte (what is questioned - a particular being).

items.name: The questioner must be made transparent in their own Being
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. Since questioning is itself a mode of Being, the entity that questions must be ontologically clarified to make the question of Being transparent.

items.name: Humans are the entity whose Being includes the possibility of questioning Being
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: IMPLICIT. Heidegger assumes that among all entities, only human beings have the ontological structure that makes questioning Being possible - though this anthropocentrism will be heavily criticized.

items.name: This questioning entity is designated 'Dasein'
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. Dasein is the technical term for the entity which each of us is, characterized essentially by its relationship to the question of Being.

items.name: The hermeneutical circle: questioning Being requires prior understanding of Being
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: IMPLICIT. The apparent circularity that we must already understand Being to question it productively, which Heidegger will argue is not vicious but reveals Being's unique structure.

items.name: Therefore, fundamental ontology must begin with the analytic of Dasein
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: EXPLICIT. The formal structure of the question demands that we begin by making Dasein ontologically transparent as the pathway to understanding Being in general.

items.name: Dasein has ontological priority over other entities
items.speaker: Heidegger
items.description: IMPLICIT. Heidegger assumes Dasein's Being-relationship grants it privileged access to Being in general, making it the proper starting point for fundamental ontology rather than merely one being among others.

children.name: Standard Objections and Critical Assessment
children.subtitle: Major philosophical criticisms of Heidegger's approach

items.name: Carnap's Elimination Thesis
items.speaker: Rudolf Carnap
items.description: Rudolf Carnap argued in 'The Elimination of Metaphysics' (1932) that Heidegger's statements about 'Being' and 'Nothing' are pseudo-propositions lacking cognitive content, violating logical syntax and empirical verifiability criteria.

items.name: Ryle's Category Mistake Objection
items.speaker: Gilbert Ryle
items.description: Gilbert Ryle contended that Heidegger systematically conflates logical categories with existential ones, treating 'Being' as if it were a special kind of entity rather than a logical concept, committing systematic category mistakes.

items.name: Levinas's Ethics-First Critique
items.speaker: Emmanuel Levinas
items.description: Emmanuel Levinas argued in 'Totality and Infinity' (1961) that fundamental ontology improperly subordinates ethics to ontology, making the face-to-face encounter with the Other secondary to the question of Being, thereby missing the primordial ethical dimension.

items.name: The Anthropocentrism Objection
items.speaker: Various Critics
items.description: Critics argue that beginning with Dasein makes fundamental ontology ultimately anthropocentric, despite Heidegger's claims to overcome traditional subject-object metaphysics. This contradicts the universality claimed for the Being-question.

items.name: The Analytic Rigor Critique
items.speaker: Bertrand Russell et al.
items.description: Analytic philosophers from Russell to contemporary figures argue that Heidegger's method lacks the logical precision and argumentative rigor required for genuine philosophical analysis, relying on etymological word-play and obscure terminology.

items.name: The Circularity Problem
items.speaker: Various Critics
items.description: Critics argue that the hermeneutical circle renders the inquiry methodologically invalid: if we must already understand Being to question it, then the analysis cannot yield genuinely new knowledge about Being's meaning.

items.name: The Temporal Chauvinism Objection
items.speaker: Various Critics
items.description: Critics argue that Heidegger's critique of presence-metaphysics itself privileges temporality in a way that may be no less metaphysically dogmatic than the tradition he opposes, merely substituting temporal for spatial metaphors.
